A Brief Communication entitled ‘ Cell type-specific expression of the putative SARS-CoV-2 receptor ACE2 in human hearts’, Stefanie Dimmeler et al. from the Johan-Wolfgang Goethe Universität in Frankfurt am Main, Germany continue on the subject.
14 They determined the tissue levels of ACE2 where SARS-CoV-2 binds via its glycosylated outer membrane spike proteins. They found that ACE2 is highly expressed in the lung and heart, complementing previous observations that it is increased in myocardial infarction.
15 Although SARS-CoV-2 mainly invades alveolar epithelial cells, it can also cause myocardial injury, as assessed by increased troponin T and NT-proBNP levels in COVID-19-infected patients, as further outlined in this issue.
